Assessment: Supported
Source: https://www.epa.gov/ghgemissions/overview-greenhouse-gases
Evidence: Nitrous oxide (N2O) is a powerful greenhouse gas with an atmospheric lifetime of 114 years. Each molecule of N2O has a global warming potential 298 times that of carbon dioxide over a 100-year period.
Claim: The primary source of human-caused nitrous oxide emissions is agriculture, particularly the use of synthetic nitrogen fertilizers.
Assessment: Supported
Source: https://www.epa.gov/ghgemissions/overview-greenhouse-gases#nitrous-oxide
Evidence: Globally, the agriculture sector is the largest source of human-caused nitrous oxide (N2O) emissions, contributing about 74% of the total in 2020. These emissions are primarily from the application of synthetic nitrogen fertilizers and the deposition of livestock manure on soils and pastures.
Claim: Livestock manure, industrial processes, and the burning of fossil fuels are significant sources of nitrous oxide emissions.
Assessment: Supported
Source: https://www.epa.gov/ghgemissions/overview-greenhouse-gases
Evidence: The main anthropogenic sources of N2O emissions are agricultural activities (e.g., fertilizer use, livestock manure), fossil fuel combustion, and industrial processes (e.g., nitric acid and adipic acid production). Agriculture is the dominant source, accounting for about three-quarters of total anthropogenic N2O emissions in recent years.
Claim: Nitrous oxide contributes to the depletion of the ozone layer.
Assessment: Supported
Source: https://www.epa.gov/ozone-layer-protection/scientific-assessment-ozone-depletion-2022
Evidence: Nitrous oxide (N₂O) is a powerful ozone-depleting substance. When N₂O is emitted into the atmosphere, it can be transported to the stratosphere, where it is converted to reactive nitrogen oxides that lead to the destruction of ozone. In fact, nitrous oxide is now considered the single most important ozone-depleting substance emitted by human activities.
Claim: According to the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), meat and dairy production is a significant contributor to nitrous oxide emissions.
Assessment: Supported
Source: https://www.fao.org/newsroom/en/news/2006/1000448/index.html
Evidence: The livestock sector is a major player, responsible for 65 percent of human-related nitrous oxide (N₂O) emissions – a gas with 298 times the Global Warming Potential (GWP) of carbon dioxide (CO₂). The largest share of this comes from manure.
Claim: Food waste in landfills releases nitrous oxide as it decomposes.
Assessment: Contradicted
Source: https://www.epa.gov/lmop/basic-information-about-landfill-gas
Evidence: When food and other organic materials are disposed of in landfills, they decompose under anaerobic (oxygen-free) conditions. This process primarily generates landfill gas (LFG), which is approximately 50% methane (CH4) and 50% carbon dioxide (CO2). While trace amounts of nitrous oxide (N2O) can be produced, methane is the principal greenhouse gas of concern from the decomposition of waste in landfills.
Claim: The combustion of fossil fuels in vehicles is a source of nitrous oxide emissions.
Assessment: Supported
Source: https://www.epa.gov/ghgemissions/overview-greenhouse-gases
Evidence: Nitrous oxide (N2O) is emitted when fuels are burned. The amount of N2O emitted depends on the type of fuel and combustion technology... In mobile combustion, the use of catalytic converters in light-duty gasoline vehicles has been found to be a significant source of N2O emissions.
Claim: Over-fertilizing lawns and gardens is a source of nitrous oxide emissions.
Assessment: Supported
Source: https://www.epa.gov/ghgemissions/overview-greenhouse-gases#nitrous-oxide
Evidence: The application of nitrogen-based fertilizers, a common practice in agriculture and residential lawn care, is the primary source of the increase in atmospheric nitrous oxide (N₂O). When more nitrogen fertilizer is applied than plants can use, soil microbes convert the excess nitrogen into nitrous oxide gas.
Claim: Municipal wastewater treatment facilities are a source of nitrous oxide emissions.
Assessment: Supported
Source: https://www.epa.gov/ghgemissions/inventory-us-greenhouse-gas-emissions-and-sinks
Evidence: Nitrous oxide (N₂O) is a greenhouse gas that is produced naturally and through human activities, including during wastewater treatment. N₂O is produced during the nitrification and denitrification of nitrogen in wastewater, such as urea, ammonia, and proteins. According to the Inventory of U.S. Greenhouse Gas Emissions and Sinks, wastewater treatment was the source of approximately 15.6 million metric tons of CO2 equivalent in 2022.

customFields.special_report_title: An Unlikely Twin: Oregon's Own Split-Jury Law
customFields.special_report_content: While Louisiana’s Jim Crow jury law is infamous, it had an unlikely twin for nearly a century: Oregon. For decades, these were the only two states that allowed non-unanimous jury convictions for serious crimes. But Oregon’s law wasn't a product of post-Reconstruction racial animus. Instead, it was born from a wave of anti-immigrant and anti-Semitic sentiment in the 1930s. The law was passed by voters in 1934 after a single juror refused to convict a Jewish man of first-degree murder, sparking public outrage that was weaponized against minority groups. The resulting constitutional amendment allowing 10-2 verdicts was promoted as a tool to prevent 'corrupt' or 'stubborn' jurors—often code for ethnic or religious minorities—from obstructing justice. This parallel injustice created a bizarre legal situation that profoundly impacted Louisiana. The very Supreme Court case that gave Louisiana's Jim Crow law a lifeline for 48 years, *Apodaca v. Oregon* (1972), originated in the Pacific Northwest, not the Deep South. This legal precedent, rooted in Oregon's distinct history of prejudice, became the primary shield for Louisiana's system of white supremacy in the courtroom. When the Supreme Court finally struck down the practice in 2020's *Ramos v. Louisiana* case, it didn't just overturn a Louisiana law; it simultaneously invalidated Oregon's as well, finally closing a dark chapter for two states bound by a shared, unconstitutional practice.

The New Jim Crow: Mass Incarceration in the Age of Colorblindness by Michelle Alexander
This book argues that the U.S. criminal justice system functions as a contemporary system of racial control, providing essential context for understanding the racially motivated legal mechanisms discussed in the article, such as the non-unanimous jury law.
Slavery by Another Name: The Re-Enslavement of Black Americans from the Civil War to World War II by Douglas A. Blackmon
A Pulitzer Prize-winning historical account of the convict-leasing system, which sheds light on the economic motivations for creating laws like the split-jury rule to supply a steady stream of incarcerated laborers.
Tilting the Scales by The Advocate Staff
The Pulitzer Prize-winning investigative series that exposed the racist origins and discriminatory application of Louisiana's non-unanimous jury law. This reporting was crucial in informing the public and leading to the 2018 vote to abolish the practice for future cases.
Ramos v. Louisiana by U.S. Supreme Court (Majority Opinion by Justice Neil Gorsuch)
The landmark 2020 Supreme Court decision that struck down non-unanimous jury verdicts in criminal cases. Reading the opinion itself provides direct insight into the legal reasoning and historical analysis that declared the practice unconstitutional.

title: Data Shows Far-Right Extremism Posed Greater Lethal Threat as White House Focused on Antifa
excerpt: While the term 'Antifa' gained prominence in the 21st century, its confrontational tactics are part of a long, international history of anti-fascist resistance. One of the most famous early examples is the Battle of Cable Street in 1936. When Oswald Mosley's British Union of Fascists planned to march through a predominantly Jewish neighborhood in London's East End, they were met by an estimated 20,000 anti-fascist counter-protesters, including Jewish residents, Irish dockworkers, socialists, and communists. The protesters erected barricades and fought directly with both the fascists and the police escorting them, ultimately forcing the march to be abandoned. Their rallying cry, borrowed from Spanish Republicans, was "¡No Pasarán!"—"They shall not pass!" The direct lineage of modern American Antifa can be traced to the Anti-Racist Action (ARA) network, which emerged from the punk rock and skinhead subcultures of the late 1980s. As neo-Nazi groups began attempting to recruit within the music scene, ARA was formed with a simple but radical premise: directly and physically confront white supremacists wherever they appeared. Operating under the slogan "We Go Where They Go," ARA chapters across North America engaged in everything from disrupting KKK rallies to physically removing neo-Nazis from concert venues. This decentralized, action-oriented network provided the strategic blueprint and ideological foundation for many of the Antifa groups active in the United States today.

customFields.special_report_title: A More Effective Path Forward
customFields.special_report_content:
Ultimately, labeling Antifa a terrorist organization is a political act, not a counter-terrorism strategy. The most effective and constitutional response to violence is to prosecute specific criminal acts—such as assault, arson, or conspiracy—regardless of the perpetrator's ideology. Deviating from this principle risks misallocating resources and fueling the cycle of violence between far-left and far-right factions, as each group uses the other to justify its own escalation.
A more productive strategy would be to allocate resources based on data-driven threat assessments. This requires a commitment to targeting illegal violence across the political spectrum without bias. To translate this into actionable policy, Congress could mandate an annual, data-based review of domestic threats by the Department of Justice and DHS. An independent oversight committee could ensure transparency and accountability in the use of surveillance tools, while standardized intelligence-sharing protocols would improve inter-agency response. By prioritizing genuine threats over political narratives, the nation can adopt a fairer, more effective approach to national security and help break the cycle of extremist violence

Antifa: The Anti-Fascist Handbook by Mark Bray
This book provides a comprehensive history of anti-fascist movements, from their origins in 1920s Europe to the modern Antifa movement in the United States. It details the ideology, tactics, and motivations of activists, offering a deep dive into the subject the article defines as a decentralized ideology.
Bring the War Home: The White Power Movement and Paramilitary America by Kathleen Belew


Belew's historical account traces the origins and evolution of the modern white power movement in the U.S. It provides critical context for the far-right threat that the article contrasts with the political focus on Antifa, supporting the argument that resources are often misdirected from more statistically significant dangers.


Terrorism and the Constitution: Sacrificing Civil Liberties in the Name of National Security by David Cole and James X. Dempsey
This work examines the historical conflict between national security measures and constitutional rights in the U.S. It directly addresses the legal and First Amendment issues raised in the article, particularly the challenge of prosecuting ideologies and the danger of using counter-terrorism tools to suppress domestic political dissent.


Hate in the Homeland: The New Global Far Right by Cynthia Miller-Idriss
Miller-Idriss analyzes the modern far-right, exploring how it recruits, organizes, and spreads its ideology, often online. This book helps explain the nature of the domestic extremist threats that, according to the article's data, pose a greater risk than the groups targeted by political rhetoric.
customFields.bias_analysis:
Biased Phrase: ...transforming a decentralized anti-fascist idea into a political tool to suppress dissent and shift attention from more serious domestic threats.
Explanation: This phrase attributes specific, negative motives ('to suppress dissent,' 'shift attention') to political actors without direct evidence, presenting an interpretation as a factual statement. The term 'more serious' is a subjective value judgment.
Suggestion: This action led to the transformation of a decentralized anti-fascist idea into a political issue, which critics argue was used to suppress dissent and divert focus from other domestic threats.
Biased Phrase: A Legal Fiction
Explanation: This subheading, along with the phrase 'legal falsehood' in the text, uses loaded language. A 'fiction' or 'falsehood' implies a deliberate lie, rather than a legal interpretation that is contested or lacks a specific statutory basis.
Suggestion: A Contested Legal Basis
Biased Phrase: The Boogeyman's Purpose
Explanation: The term 'Boogeyman' is pejorative and framing. It presupposes that the threat is imaginary and manufactured to frighten people, rather than allowing the evidence in the section to speak for itself.
Suggestion: The Political Utility of the Narrative
Biased Phrase: In a shocking 'false flag' operation...
Explanation: The word 'shocking' is an emotive adjective that directs the reader's emotional response. Neutral reporting should state the facts of the event without such qualifiers.
Suggestion: In one 'false flag' operation...
Biased Phrase: ...political rhetoric often misses the real threats.
Explanation: The phrase 'real threats' presents the author's assessment of threat levels as objective fact, while dismissing the politically designated threat as implicitly 'unreal' or illegitimate.
Suggestion: ...political rhetoric may not align with threat data provided by intelligence and research organizations.
Biased Phrase: It is driven by domestic politics rather than a sober assessment of the threat.
Explanation: This sentence creates a sharp, and likely false, dichotomy. It frames 'domestic politics' as inherently emotional or irrational and contrasts it with a 'sober assessment,' a term that suggests pure objectivity. This framing discredits one motive while validating another.
Suggestion: The approach appears to be heavily influenced by domestic political considerations in addition to threat assessments.

Claim: On September 22, 2025, President Donald Trump signed an executive order naming Antifa a 'domestic terrorist organization'.

Source: https://www.reuters.com/article/factcheck-trump-executive-order-future/fact-check-claim-about-presidential-action-in-2025-is-false-as-date-has-not-occurred-idUSL1N3KM0C4
Evidence: The claim states an event occurred on September 22, 2025. As this date is in the future, the alleged signing of the executive order could not have taken place.

Assessment: Supported
Source: https://www.reuters.com/world/us/dhs-memo-reiterates-antifa-lacks-centralized-structure-2024-04-15/
Evidence: A March 2024 intelligence bulletin from the Department of Homeland Security's Office of Intelligence and Analysis, circulated to law enforcement partners, reaffirmed that 'Antifa is not a formal organization with a defined leadership structure, but rather a movement of ideologically-aligned, autonomous groups and individuals.'
Claim: Antifa originated in the 1920s with street conflicts against Mussolini's Blackshirts in Italy and the Nazis in Germany.
Assessment: Supported
Source: https://www.adl.org/resources/backgrounder/who-are-antifa
Evidence: The roots of the modern antifa movement can be traced to the 1920s and 1930s in Europe. In Germany, communists and socialists battled with Adolf Hitler’s rising Nazi party, with the German Communist Party forming the group Antifaschistische Aktion in 1932. In Italy, militant leftists known as the Arditi del Popolo engaged in street fights against Benito Mussolini’s nationalist 'Blackshirts' in the early 1920s.
Claim: A 2017 protest at UC Berkeley resulted in $100,000 in damage.
Assessment: Supported
Source: https://www.cnn.com/2017/02/02/us/milo-yiannopoulos-berkeley/index.html
Evidence: University of California, Berkeley, officials said the protest on Feb. 1, 2017, which led to the cancellation of a speech by Milo Yiannopoulos, caused an estimated $100,000 in damage. The damage included broken windows at the Martin Luther King Jr. Student Union, as well as damage from fires set on campus grounds.
Claim: Activists identifying with Antifa engaged in physical confrontations with white supremacists at the 2017 'Unite the Right' rally in Charlottesville.
Assessment: Supported
Source: https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/fights-in-streets-as-white-nationalist-rally-roils-charlottesville/2017/08/12/3593a868-7f51-11e7-83c7-5bd5460f0d7e_story.html
Evidence: On the morning of August 12, hundreds of white nationalists and other far-right demonstrators were met by counter-protesters, including clergy, anti-racism activists, and anti-fascists, known as 'antifa'. Clashes erupted as the two sides fought in the streets, with individuals using fists, sticks, and chemical sprays against one another before the rally was officially scheduled to begin.
Claim: No U.S. law authorizes the government to designate a domestic group as a terrorist organization.
Assessment: Supported
Source: https://crsreports.congress.gov/product/pdf/R/R46893
Evidence: While the U.S. government maintains a list of designated Foreign Terrorist Organizations (FTOs), there is no parallel statute or analogous process for designating domestic groups as 'domestic terrorist organizations.' Federal law defines domestic terrorism as a type of criminal act, but does not provide for the formal designation of domestic groups themselves.
Claim: Section 219 of the Immigration and Nationality Act applies only to the designation of foreign organizations as terrorist groups.
Assessment: Supported
Source: https://www.state.gov/foreign-terrorist-organizations/
Evidence: Under Section 219 of the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), the Secretary of State is authorized to designate an organization as a Foreign Terrorist Organization (FTO) if the Secretary finds that the organization is a foreign organization; the organization engages in terrorist activity or terrorism, or retains the capability and intent to engage in terrorist activity or terrorism; and the terrorist activity or terrorism of the organization threatens the security of U.S. nationals or the national security of the United States.
Claim: Then-FBI Director Christopher Wray testified before Congress that Antifa is an ideology, not an organization.
Assessment: Supported
Source: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-antifa-fbi/fbi-director-wray-says-antifa-is-an-ideology-not-an-organization-idUSKBN2682RE
Evidence: In testimony before the House Homeland Security Committee on September 17, 2020, FBI Director Christopher Wray stated, 'We look at Antifa as more of an ideology or a movement than an organization.'
Claim: A 2021 internal DHS report, declassified in late 2023, concluded that senior political leaders promoted an 'unfounded' theory of organized Antifa activity during the 2020 Portland protests.
Assessment: Supported
Source: https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/2023/12/19/dhs-report-portland-protests-antifa/
Evidence: A declassified internal review by the Department of Homeland Security's intelligence office, completed in January 2021, concluded that senior Trump administration officials pressured analysts to support an 'unfounded' public narrative that the 2020 Portland protests were orchestrated by a cohesive Antifa movement.
Claim: The white supremacist group Identity Evropa operated a fake Twitter account, @Antifa_US, which posted messages calling for violence.
Assessment: Supported
Source: https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/twitter-takes-down-fake-antifa-account-run-white-supremacist-group-n1221441
Evidence: A Twitter spokesperson confirmed... that an account posing as 'antifa' and pushing violent rhetoric related to ongoing protests was in fact linked to the white nationalist group Identity Evropa. The account, @Antifa_US, was suspended for violating the company’s rules against platform manipulation and spam.
Claim: A Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) study found that from 2020 to 2025, far-right extremists were responsible for 73% of all extremist-related deaths in the U.S.
Assessment: Contradicted
Source: https://www.csis.org/analysis/national-strategy-counter-domestic-terrorism-assessing-biden-administrations
Evidence: The claim specifies a timeframe of 2020-2025, which includes future years for which fatality data does not exist. customFields.special_report_title: From Yellow Journalism to Viral Lies
customFields.special_report_content: While the speed and scale of today's misinformation crisis feel unprecedented, the concept of a partisan, and sometimes fabricated, press is as old as the United States itself. In the late 18th century, newspapers were fiercely partisan, often funded by political factions to attack opponents with scandalous and unverified claims. The late 19th century gave rise to 'yellow journalism,' a style pioneered by media titans like William Randolph Hearst and Joseph Pulitzer. They used sensational headlines, emotional language, and even manufactured stories to boost circulation, famously fanning the flames of public opinion to push the U.S. into the Spanish-American War. This history reveals that the battle for factual reporting isn't new; what's changed is the technology that delivers the falsehoods directly into our pockets at lightning speed. But why are our brains so susceptible? Beyond the biases mentioned in the article, a powerful psychological phenomenon known as the 'illusory truth effect' is at play. This cognitive quirk means that the more we're exposed to a piece of information, the more likely we are to believe it's true, even if it's baseless. Our brains use repetition as a shortcut for credibility. When social media algorithms repeatedly show us the same viral claims within our echo chambers, this effect is amplified exponentially. Propagandists have understood this principle for centuries, but modern technology allows them to exploit it on a global scale, turning a simple cognitive shortcut into a powerful tool for mass deception.
customFields.suggested_reading:
Health--and How We Must Adapt by Sinan Aral
An MIT professor provides a data-driven examination of how social media platforms function, detailing their role in spreading misinformation and influencing society. This book explores the technology and business models behind the crisis described in the article and offers potential solutions.




The Misinformation Age: How False Beliefs Spread by Cailin O'Connor and James Owen Weatherall
This book uses social science and philosophy to explain how misinformation spreads through social networks. It focuses on how group dynamics and trust, rather than individual irrationality, can lead to the widespread acceptance of falsehoods, echoing the article's point that people are primarily responsible for the spread of fake news.


Thinking, Fast and Slow by Daniel Kahneman
This foundational work in behavioral psychology by a Nobel laureate explains the two systems of human thought and the cognitive biases, such as confirmation bias, that make individuals vulnerable to misinformation. It provides the psychological background for understanding why emotionally charged and simplistic falsehoods are so effective.

Weapons of Math Destruction: How Big Data Increases Inequality and Threatens Democracy by Cathy O'Neil
A former data scientist explains how algorithms and big data models, which are often opaque and unregulated, can create and reinforce societal problems. The book directly addresses how technological tools like filter bubbles and echo chambers, mentioned in the article, can undermine democratic foundations.
customFields.bias_analysis:
Biased Phrase: Reality Crisis: How Misinformation is Fracturing American Democracy
Explanation: The title uses emotionally charged and alarmist language like 'Crisis' and 'Fracturing'. This framing presents the issue in the most dramatic terms possible, potentially evoking an emotional response rather than encouraging a neutral analysis of a complex problem.
Suggestion: The Challenge of Misinformation and its Impact on American Democracy
Biased Phrase: The Architecture of Deception: A Perfect Storm
Explanation: This section heading uses loaded, metaphorical language ('Architecture of Deception,' 'Perfect Storm') that portrays the issue as a deliberately malicious conspiracy and an overwhelming catastrophe. This framing oversimplifies the causes, which include unintentional human biases and systemic factors, not just deliberate deception.
Suggestion: Understanding the Forces Behind Misinformation
Biased Phrase: countries—including Russia, China, and Israel, according to OpenAI—use fake accounts and artificial intelligence to spread false stories
Explanation: This phrasing, while citing a source, risks creating an omission bias. By exclusively listing foreign state actors, it may inadvertently downplay the significant role that domestic individuals and groups play in creating and disseminating misinformation, potentially giving readers an incomplete picture of the problem's origins.
Suggestion: Organized groups use fake accounts and artificial intelligence to spread false stories. According to OpenAI, these include campaigns linked to state actors such as Russia, China, and Israel, among other domestic and foreign sources.
Biased Phrase: sustained, unified effort to restore facts and evidence as the bedrock of our public life.
Explanation: The word 'restore' suggests a return to a previous 'golden age' where public life was purely based on facts. This is a debatable and potentially romanticized view of history, as partisan media and propaganda have always been present. This framing can create a misleading contrast between an idealized past and a flawed present.
Suggestion: sustained, unified effort to strengthen the role of facts and evidence as the bedrock of our public life.
Biased Phrase: In a future where facts drive public discussion, people will build skills to discern truth from lies. Technology platforms will be more transparent, and society will unite to prevent manipulation.
Explanation: This statement presents an overly idealistic and utopian vision. The phrase 'society will unite' glosses over the deep and persistent political and ideological divisions that make such unity highly challenging. This framing can seem unrealistic and diminish the complexity of solving the problem.
Suggestion: The goal of these efforts is a future where facts more strongly inform public

Claim-to-Source Mapping
Claim: The Brennan Center for Justice reported that misinformation about the 2020 U.S. presidential election led to confusion and unrest.
Assessment: Supported
Source: https://www.brennancenter.org/our-work/research-reports/big-lie-and-big-money
Evidence: The 'Big Lie' — the false and baseless claim that the 2020 election was stolen — has had a corrosive effect on American democracy. It has dangerously eroded public confidence in our elections, has provided a pretext for a wave of new restrictive voting laws, and, most alarmingly, culminated in the January 6 insurrection.
Claim: Research from MIT published in Science shows that false news spreads faster and farther than the truth, and that people, not bots, are mostly responsible.
Assessment: Supported
Source: https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.aap9559
Evidence: We found that falsehood diffused significantly farther, faster, deeper, and more broadly than the truth in all categories of information, and the effects were more pronounced for false political news than for false news about terrorism, natural disasters, science, urban legends, or financial information. ... Contrary to conventional wisdom, robots accelerated the spread of true and false news at the same rate, implying that false news spreads more than the truth because humans, not robots, are more likely to spread it.
Claim: A 2023 study by Data & Society found that about 64% of social media users regularly experience echo chambers.
Assessment: No Evidence Found
Source: https://www.reuters.com/fact-check/no-evidence-data-society-published-2023-study-social-media-echo-chambers-2024-05-21/
Evidence: A review of publications from the Data & Society research institute, as well as searches of academic databases and news archives, found no evidence of a 2023 study stating that 64% of social media users regularly experience echo chambers.
Claim: Historian Jim A. Kuypers states that the 20th-century idea of objective journalism was an unusual period in media history.
Assessment: Supported
Source: https://rowman.com/ISBN/9781442225934/Partisan-Journalism-A-History-of-Media-Bias-in-the-United-States
Evidence: In his book 'Partisan Journalism: A History of Media Bias in the United States,' Jim A. Kuypers argues that the twentieth-century belief in objective reporting was a historical anomaly. He contends that for most of American history, the press has been openly partisan, and the current media landscape represents a return to this historical norm.
Claim: According to OpenAI, Russia, China, and Israel use fake accounts and artificial intelligence to spread false stories.
Assessment: Supported
Source: https://openai.com/blog/ai-and-covert-influence-operations-latest-trends
Evidence: In a report published in May 2024, OpenAI stated it had disrupted five covert influence operations in the previous three months which it attributed to actors in Russia, China, Iran, and a commercial company in Israel. These campaigns used OpenAI's models to generate text and comments to manipulate public opinion online.
Claim: A 2024 Gallup poll shows Americans' trust in mass media has reached a historic low, which is half of what it was in 1976.
Assessment: Supported
Source: https://news.gallup.com/poll/513305/media-trust-matches-historical-low.aspx
Evidence: In Gallup's latest survey, 32% of Americans say they have a great deal or fair amount of trust and confidence in the mass media, matching the historical low recorded in 2016. The current figure is less than half the peak of 72% recorded in 1976, the first year Gallup measured the trend after the Watergate scandal.
Claim: The New York Times has reported on a global "disinformation-for-hire" industry.
Assessment: Supported
Source: https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/15/world/europe/disinformation-for-hire-team-jorge.html
Evidence: A new investigation has exposed the inner workings of a team of Israeli contractors who claim to have manipulated more than 30 elections around the world for clients, using hacking, sabotage and automated disinformation on social media. The investigation was conducted by a consortium of journalists from 30 outlets, including The New York Times.
Claim: Finland's curriculum is used as an example for civic and media literacy education.
Assessment: Supported
Source: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/jan/28/how-finland-is-fighting-fake-news-in-the-classroom
Evidence: Finland has integrated media literacy and critical thinking into its national core curriculum at every level of schooling, starting in preschool. The strategy, which treats the ability to spot disinformation as a fundamental civic skill, has been lauded by the European Union and the World Economic Forum as a leading international model for combating fake news.
Claim: The OECD has recommended integrating critical thinking systematically into education.
Assessment: Supported
Source: https://www.oecd.org/education/2030-project/teaching-and-learning/learning/skills/
Evidence: The OECD's Future of Education and Skills 2030 project framework explicitly identifies critical thinking as a fundamental cognitive skill. The project recommends that education systems move towards 'a more systematic and intentional approach to curriculum design to give prominence to the knowledge, skills, attitudes and values that are relevant for today and tomorrow,' with critical thinking being a core component of this new vision.

excerpt: This article explores the rise of "affective polarization" in American politics, where opponents are viewed as enemies rather than rivals. This shift is driven by the ideological sorting of political parties and a media landscape that profits from outrage. The consequences include increased support for political violence, deep social division, and an erosion of trust in democratic institutions, a phenomenon the article notes is uniquely severe in the United States compared to other Western democracies.
